llm.i: Self-assessment for developers - be honest about what's actually done
Mark items as ✅ Done, ❌ Not Done, or N/A Not Applicable
Add brief comments explaining any ❌ or N/A items
Be specific about what was actually implemented
Flag any concerns or technical debt created
The goal is quality delivery, not just checking boxes

section.name: 1. Requirements Met
section.desc: Verify all story requirements are implemented
section.llm: Be specific - list each requirement and whether it's complete

subsection.name: 1.1 Core Requirements
subsection.i: All functional requirements specified in the story are implemented
All acceptance criteria defined in the story are met

section.name: 2. Coding Standards and Project Structure
section.desc: Code quality and adherence to standards
section.llm: Code quality matters for maintainability - check each item carefully

subsection.name: 2.1 Standards Compliance
subsection.i: All new/modified code strictly adheres to Operational Guidelines
All new/modified code aligns with Project Structure (file locations, naming, etc.)
Adherence to Tech Stack for technologies/versions used (if story introduces or modifies tech usage)
Adherence to API Reference and Data Models (if story involves API or data model changes)
Basic security best practices (e.g., input validation, proper error handling, no hardcoded secrets) applied for new/modified code
No new linter errors or warnings introduced
Code is well-commented where necessary (clarifying complex logic, not obvious statements)

section.name: 3. Testing
section.llm: Testing proves your code works - be honest about test coverage

subsection.name: 3.1 Test Implementation
subsection.i: All required unit tests as per the story and Operational Guidelines Testing Strategy are implemented
All required integration tests (if applicable) as per the story and Operational Guidelines Testing Strategy are implemented
All tests (unit, integration, E2E if applicable) pass successfully
Test coverage meets project standards (if defined)

section.name: 4. Functionality and Verification
section.llm: Did you actually run and test your code? Be specific about what you tested

subsection.name: 4.1 Manual Verification
subsection.i: Functionality has been manually verified by the developer (e.g., running the app locally, checking UI, testing API endpoints)
Edge cases and potential error conditions considered and handled gracefully

section.name: 5. Story Administration
section.llm: Documentation helps the next developer - what should they know?

subsection.name: 5.1 Story Documentation
subsection.i: All tasks within the story file are marked as complete
Any clarifications or decisions made during development are documented in the story file or linked appropriately

The story wrap up section has been completed with notes of changes or information relevant to the next story or overall project, the agent model that was primarily used during development, and the changelog of any changes is properly updated

section.name: 6. Dependencies, Build and Configuration
section.llm: Build issues block everyone - ensure everything compiles and runs cleanly

subsection.name: 6.1 Build Success
subsection.i: Project builds successfully without errors
Project linting passes

subsection.name: 6.2 Dependency Management
subsection.i: Any new dependencies added were either pre-approved in the story requirements OR explicitly approved by the user during development (approval documented in story file)
If new dependencies were added, they are recorded in the appropriate project files (e.g., package.json, requirements.txt) with justification
No known security vulnerabilities introduced by newly added and approved dependencies
If new environment variables or configurations were introduced by the story, they are documented and handled securely

section.name: 7. Documentation (If Applicable)
section.llm: Good documentation prevents future confusion - what needs explaining?

subsection.name: 7.1 Documentation Updates
subsection.i: Relevant inline code documentation (e.g., JSDoc, TSDoc, Python docstrings) for new public APIs or complex logic is complete
User-facing documentation updated, if changes impact users
Technical documentation (e.g., READMEs, system diagrams) updated if significant architectural changes were made

section.name: 8. Final Confirmation
section.llm: Be honest - it's better to flag issues now than have them discovered later

subsection.name: 8.1 Developer Confirmation
subsection.i: I, the Developer Agent, confirm that all applicable items above have been addressed

report.overall-status: Summarize what was accomplished in this story
report.incomplete: List any items marked as Not Done with explanations
report.tech-debt: Identify any technical debt or follow-up work needed
report.learnings: Note any challenges or learnings for future stories
report.ready: Confirm whether the story is truly ready for review
